comments:
I wanted to see the Hierarchy of Exception, marked it in an Editor and pressed
F4. I got the message "Creating Hierarchy failed. See log for details".
(Same problem on 3.1 RC3, RC4, Final. On 3.0.1 it works fine)

The Error log says this:

This error occurs for me when I try to view the hierarchy for many classes, 
such as javax.swing.AbstractButton. In fact, it happens for most of the useful 
base classes in the JDK! I would like to request the the severity be increased 
to major: I think that View Hierarchy is often used for standard base classes.

I've tried to reproduce the cases mentioned in this PR, but all work fine for 
me with the latest builds (after 3.2M2).

Can anyone reproduce their problem on the latest 3.2 stream build?

I just tried this with 3.2 M2. With my normal workspace, AbstractButton now 
works, but JDialog fails.
I have a lot of classes in my normal workspace; if I use a minimal workspace, 
JDialog and Object both work.
So it's better in 3.2 M@, but not completely fixed.

The latest fix is not in 3.2M2.

Please try the latest nightly build.

I tried the build eclipse-SDK-N20050929-0010-win32.zip with my usual workspace 
and it failed to get the hierarchy for AbstractButton. The root cause is a 
StackOverflowException.

What is the command line to start your workspace? You likely need to increase 
the initial heap size of the VM.

In my workspace, I can open the hierarchy of AbstractButton with no problems.

I was using the default command line. I tried adding '-vmargs -Xmx[n]M' where 
[n] is 128, 256 and 512. I still get a stack overflow. I have 2 GB of RAM.

I wonder if there's someting about the classes in my workspace that is causing 
an infinite recursion. Viewing the hierarchy of Object succeeds (with a 512M 
heap), so it's not a problem with the number of immediate children!

Can you please send us your workspace so we can figure out the infinite loop?

And if not can you narrow down a testcase for us?

I don't believe it's the same problem as 103466. I just tried viewing the

Rick, I cannot reproduce this problem either. There must be something special

would be great. Also can you please attach the trace of the StackOverflowError
to this bug ?

Do other people CC'ed on this bug still have a StackOverflowError with I20051018
or M20050929 ?

I have tracked the problem down to a commercial library we're using. If the JAR 
file is referenced by a project in the workspace, the stack overflow occurs. If 
it's not referenced, or if I delete the JAR file, I can view the type hierarchy 
successfully.
The company that produces the library has given me permission to send you a 
copy, but has asked me not to post it in a public area. The JAR file is about 1 
MB large. Can I email it to someone?
Cheers
- rick

The JAR has a class named a$a.class which is impossible to produce by a JCK
compliant compiler since a member type cannot have the same simple name as its
enclosing type.
I will see if I can workaround this anomaly.

Which of the JAR files has the problematic class? 
I think it would be great if you can make Eclipse capable of handling this; but 
I may be able to get the JAR file(s) changed to avoid this, which would solve 
the problem for me.

The StackOverflowError is caused by a$a.class [in
com.crystaldecisions.sdk.occa.security.internal [in cecore.jar]]

Changed NameLookup#seekTypesInBinaryPackage(...) to compare the expected type
name to the class file name (instead of using the local type name).
Added regression test NameLookupTests2#testFindBinaryTypeWithSameNameAsMember().

Note the fix will NOT be in 3.2 M3 but it will be in 3.2 M4.

This problem ais solved for me with the interim build of 8 November. I'll test 
again with 3.2 M4.

Thanks!

- rick cameron
